text: Congrats! I hope my face on the thumbnail doesn't scare any potential customers away :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:

elements.text: Congrats! I hope my face on the thumbnail doesn't scare any potential customers away

text: Hi Chris, do you have more details for me about the cardiac simulation? I am asking because I am a PhD candidate in computational cardiology, wanting to rewrite my electromechanics simulation framework in pure Julia soon.

elements.text: Hi Chris, do you have more details for me about the cardiac simulation? I am asking because I am a PhD candidate in computational cardiology, wanting to rewrite my electromechanics simulation framework in pure Julia soon.

text: There are multiple cardiac models. Some pulled from SBML and CellML sources, others sourced from consulting projects which I'd need to get permission first before sharing the details (which is why this isn't a full release yet!)

elements.text: There are multiple cardiac models. Some pulled from SBML and CellML sources, others sourced from consulting projects which I'd need to get permission first before sharing the details (which is why this isn't a full release yet!)

text: Ah, no problem! :blush: I just want to avoid having multiple similar frameworks and thought that I missed some open source framework for cardiac simulations in Julia.

elements.text: I just want to avoid having multiple similar frameworks and thought that I missed some open source framework for cardiac simulations in Julia.

text: This is going to be a bunch of ModelingToolkit.jl component-based models, i.e. like <https://mtk.sciml.ai/dev/tutorials/acausal_components/> where you can then connect and compose them to other models. Taken from some standard sources, though a few are coming from proprietary places (if all approvals go through). So it's moreso that there will be tons of nice starting places which you can then take the model, add to it, and go from there.

elements.text: This is going to be a bunch of ModelingToolkit.jl component-based models, i.e. like

where you can then connect and compose them to other models. Taken from some standard sources, though a few are coming from proprietary places (if all approvals go through). So it's moreso that there will be tons of nice starting places which you can then take the model, add to it, and go from there.

text: That has more of an industry focus, but of course as an academic it can be nice to just take 2,000 differential equations someone else comes up with (with docs and all)

elements.text: That has more of an industry focus, but of course as an academic it can be nice to just take 2,000 differential equations someone else comes up with (with docs and all)

text: Thanks! Yeah implementing the heart models by hand can be really some work without SBML and CellML.

elements.text: Thanks! Yeah implementing the heart models by hand can be really some work without SBML and CellML.
